activityData.title: Appreciation Mingle Greeting
activityData.description: A communication and connection activity that allows participants to exchange appreciations with each other.
activityData.preparation:
This activity can be used as part of a Morning Meeting. A space where students can safely move is important.  If you are indoors, you may request that students can walk fast as their fastest speed.

Greetings should begin with students in a circle where all are sitting and can see each other. While students are standing in a circle, you should provide students with the directions for the activity.

Morning Meeting always begins with Greeting. In Greeting, each child is welcomed by name and practices welcoming others.  The purpose of the Morning Meeting Greeting is to let our students know that we see them, we hear them, and that they belong to something important.

The goals of the Greeting component are:

  1. To set a positive tone for the day
  2. To provide a sense of recognition and belonging
  3. To help children learn and use everyoneâ€™s name
  4. To let children practice hospitality

In Greeting, children not only learn and practice the basic elements of greeting each other in a friendly way, they also gain experience in reaching across gender, clique, and friendship lines.
activityData.playing:
Steps:

  1. Say: " We are going to take a moment to show appreciation or thank our friends/classmates for things they do."
  2. Model this with one or two students. An example could be, "Sadie, thank you for being a great clean up monitor and helping to keep our classroom clean for everyone" or " Ellis, I appreciate how you always are willing to share during center time."
  3. Ask two students to model this to each other,  ensuring they use their friend's name and the sentence starter  of " (Name), Thank you for  ..." or  "(Name) I appreciate how you/that you..."
  4. Ask the whole group to think about and share out some appreciations they have for others in their group. 
  5. Say: "When I say go, walk to someone in your group/in the room and share a thank you/appreciation.  Keep going until I say stop." 
  6. Say: "When I say stop, share a thank you to the person closest to your body."
  7. This continues until everyone has appreciated everyone else in the group or until the allotted time is up.
activityData.learning:
Appreciation Mingle is designed for students to connect at the beginning of a class, mid-day, or end of day reflection. If you are interested in reflecting with students on the value of an Appreciation Mingle, please see sample reflection questions below.

Reflect: (What?)

  • What did you like about Appreciation Greetings? 
  • How did it feel to give appreciation or thank someone in your class/group?
  • How did it feel to receive appreciation or have someone thank you? 
Connect: (So what?)
  • When are times you can share an appreciation greeting? 
  • Who are some other people in our lives we can give an appreciation greeting to?  (ex. family, teachers, weekend enrichment providers, babysitters)
Grow: (Now what?)
  • How can we use appreciation greetings in our everyday life? (ex. community workers, grocery store workers, school community members, security guards)
activityData.variation: If your group is practicing social distancing, you can add in the rule that students still need to complete the actions of the handshake, yet be a certain distance apart from each other. You can ask students afterwards what elements they did that made this a greeting, EVEN THOUGH they weren't able to touch!
